question: 3 (a)
sols_html:
To solve the differential equation

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{dx}{dt}=\frac{x^2-2}{2x}\end{aligned}\]

with separation of variables we rewrite the equation as

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{2x dx}{x^2-2} = dt\end{aligned}\]

and integrate both sides

\[\begin{aligned} \int\frac{2x}{x^2-2}dx = \int 1dt.\end{aligned}\]

The integral on the right hand side simply gives t+c. The integrand on the left hand side is of the form \(\frac{f'(x)}{f(x)}\), with f(x) = x2-2, which has anti-derivative \(\ln|f(x)| = \ln|x^2-2|\). If you don’t see this easily you can simply use the substitution u = x2-2. Either way, we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \ln(|x^2-2|) = t+c\end{aligned}\]

for a constant c.

To solve this equation for x we first take the exponential on both sides

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle |x^2-2| = e^{t+c} = e^c\,e^t = de^{t},\end{aligned}\]

where d is another constant, which has to be positive. Finally, to remove the absolute value we write

\[\begin{aligned} \pm (x^2-2) = \displaystyle |x^2-2| = de^t,\end{aligned}\]

i.e.

\[\begin{aligned} x^2-2 = \pm de^t = \tilde c e^{t}\end{aligned}\]

for another constant \(\tilde c\) that has no restriction on its sign (i.e. can be positive or negative). Now we can finally solve for x and obtain

\[\begin{aligned} x(t)=\pm\sqrt{\tilde ce^t + 2}.\end{aligned}\]
